title: Financial Independence
description: Assess how you balance togetherness and autonomy with money

questions.text: I feel I have appropriate financial autonomy in our relationship.

therapeutic.rationale: Financial autonomy—having some money you control without accounting for every purchase—preserves individuality within partnership. Too little feels controlling; too much feels disconnected.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different autonomy needs require negotiation. The partner wanting more autonomy isn't rejecting partnership; the partner wanting more togetherness isn't controlling.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of appropriate autonomy creates balance between independence and partnership.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How much financial autonomy do you need to feel like yourself within your relationship?

questions.text: I respect my partner's need for some financial independence.

therapeutic.rationale: Respecting your partner's autonomy needs—even if different from yours—shows acceptance. Trying to control all spending often backfires.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel respected in their autonomy needs, explore what would help. Clear agreements? Less questioning about purchases?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual respect for independence needs creates trust and reduces financial friction.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you show respect for your partner's financial independence?

questions.text: I feel comfortable making small purchases without consulting my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: Comfort with small independent purchases reflects appropriate autonomy. Feeling you need permission for every purchase suggests an imbalanced dynamic.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different comfort levels with independent spending need discussion. What counts as 'small'? What requires consultation?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared comfort with independent small purchases indicates agreed-upon autonomy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: At what spending level do you feel you should consult your partner? Do they agree?

questions.text: I believe we balance individual and shared financial priorities well.

therapeutic.rationale: Balancing personal priorities (hobbies, self-care, individual goals) with shared ones (experiences together, joint goals) requires ongoing negotiation. Feeling balanced indicates success.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different perceptions of balance may mean one partner feels their priorities are overshadowed. Discuss what would feel more balanced.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of balance between individual and shared priorities creates satisfaction.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do your individual financial priorities get enough attention alongside shared ones?

questions.text: I trust that my partner's personal spending is reasonable.

therapeutic.rationale: Trusting your partner's independent spending choices allows autonomy without anxiety. Distrust often leads to monitoring or conflict.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't trust the other's spending, explore specific concerns. Is it about amounts? Categories? Past behavior?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual trust in each other's independent spending creates freedom within partnership.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would help you trust your partner's personal spending more fully?
